title: Pop-up Flashcards
description:
I attend Japanese classes every weekend to learn the language I wish I learned in my adolescence but one of the main problems I found during classes was that I struggled to retain the vocabulary so I built an application that can help me study even while I work.

Written in C#, it pops up based on a timer, selects a random word from a vocab list, presents multiple answers in button form and gives a couple chances to get it correct only to minimise and begins the loop again.

I'm happy with the result as through the use of this tool, I have noticed a tangible improvement on my performance in class and in general.

title: Portfolio Website
description:
"What is the best way to show your stuff? A website!"

I wanted to make one that showed my work front and centre but as cheaply as possible so I decided to make it myself and found it was a good opportunity to learn something new.

Using only HTML/CSS/JavaScript, I was able to achieve dynamically loaded content for future additions and fully mobile friendly, all hosted for free on GitHub.

Let me know what you think!

title: Corporate Automation
description:
As level 1 IT support, my role doesn't require me to do any software development but while fulfilling my duties, I found some of my responsibilities could be automated. With my programming knowledge, I decided to develop solutions to save time and effort.

One such task was access provisioning via SailPoint’s IdentityNow which is extremely slow and repetitive when provisioning multiple roles at a time. I was not part of the site team and so I couldn’t get access to the backend due to security restrictions. To get around this, I utilised Selenium via C#, to log in, do the work based on user input. I built a GUI with WinForms for input, data, logging, and progress tracking. With the experience from this, I was able to expand to other sites which required similar, repetitive work and applied the same solution. In the end I automated 4 different sites which saved hundreds of hours of manual work.

Other areas included writing VBA for quick and easy data extraction / email sending which automated repeating reports for the client. Another was writing PowerShell scripts that enabled large scale modifications to users and groups in Active Directory.

(Unfortunately I am unable to link to the source for security reasons)

title: Fireborn Menu System
description:
After the fun we had during the global game jam and the demonstration of my knowledge in Unreal Engine, Tyson from Toybox Games contracted me to build a menu system for Fireborn to use during their PAX Australia showcase.

It took around two weeks to complete and integrate into the existing project with features such as: keyboard/controller support, settings, designer customisable elements, smooth animations, and session persistency.

I built it in blueprints and created documentation for use by the designer.

(I cannot link to the source as it is currently under NDA)

title: Melbourne GGJ 2019
description:
Working with a team formed at the IGDA Melbourne meet-ups; we set out to make a homey, relaxing game set in the Australian outback. You traverse the beautiful Northern Territory as a Wedge Tail Eagle, hunting to feed your chicks.

I was in charge of the player character and the game loop, implementing a flight movement controller that could pick up prey and return them to it's nest.
